items.content_text:
Today was the first time that I had run 10 miles in a race, and therefore I started with some trepidation.

The race formed a 10 mile figure of 8 around the village of Staveley, near knaresborough. The race was largely on tracks through fields and woods, with the start, finish, and interlinking sections on roads.

The weather was pretty much perfect too, with a relatively cool temperature and light drizzle throughout.

Endomondo worked pretty well for the first 7 miles, but lost gps at the second water station and never really recovered. I‚Äôm switching back to iMapmyrun until I get a proper training watch, as it seems to deal better with this in calculating what has been missed. Miles 8 and 9 are way out, mile 10 is probably correct, given my out of body experience dancing back down the hill into the village.

I ran 8 fairly solid miles in under 8 minutes 30 apiece, but lost my way a bit in mile 9 before a quick finish. My overall times was inside the 1 hour 30 that I felt I was capable of at 1 hour 25 and 46 seconds. Thereafter I was met by Bido and Dave hughes, who had come to cheer me on (and consume real ale inside yorkshire). I need to break 8 minute miles now though to continue my progression. An excellent race, and my congratulations to the organizers, it was just a shame that the pub was fully booked and that we had to retreat to drakes fish restaurant in knaresborough to be fed.

items.content_text: My first competitive runs since fracturing my spine at 17. I didn‚Äôt really know what to expect other than hoping to come in at 10 minute miles or below. The run was a scenic tour around the lovely Newby Hall Estate above Ripon. It drizzled quite heavily throughout. Accompanied by Victoria, I was very happy with my 53:27 time and celebrated accordingly with Sunday lunch in a nearby Robinson‚Äôs pub which didn‚Äôt sell Robinson‚Äôs as their customers don‚Äôt like real ale!

items.title: Rombalds Moor
items.content_html: Richard and myself left Saltaire at around 10:30am aiming to cross over Rombalds Moor into Ilkley, getting the train back to Shipley, and walking from there. Leaving Saltaire on the Leeds ‚Äì Liverpool canal, we walked as far as Hirst Lock using the footbridge nearby to cross the River Aire and into Shipley Glen. Emerging from the glen on the road we crossed over past the farm and followed the path up to the top of Baildon Moor which although I can see it from my living room window, I had never climbed before.After leaving the summit of Baildon Moor we headed down to the road and through the golf course before following a horse training track around to Weecher Reservoir.Leaving Weecher Reservoir we walked briefly along a very busy road before heading out on the long walk up Rombald‚Äôs Moor, walking first along a wall before crossing through it and walking diagonally away from it towards the path joining from the Dales Way through a boggy section. We pasued here for a brew and to eat our lunch. Pushing onwards we came to the Twelve Apostles stone circle, were we fired off a few shots and admired the view to Drachs. We carried on for about 50m to get a photograph across Wharfedale.Leaving the path here we headed out to the summit of Rombald‚Äôs Moor through the heather. I believe there is actually a path that runs along the escarpment. After reaching the summit we headed back towards the Dalesway, but dropped off the escarpment earlier and headed diagonally across the Moor to rejoin the path lower down. This proved an error as the ground was very wet in places here. On coming to a cafe we followed the road down into Ilkley. We went to the station to check the times of the train, making the 15:53 train with about 30 seconds to spare. This walk would have been around 10 miles long.

Richard and myself left Saltaire at around 10:30am aiming to cross over Rombalds Moor into Ilkley, getting the train back to Shipley, and walking from there. Leaving Saltaire on the Leeds ‚Äì Liverpool canal, we walked as far as Hirst Lock using the footbridge nearby to cross the River Aire and into Shipley Glen. Emerging from the glen on the road we crossed over past the farm and followed the path up to the top of Baildon Moor which although I can see it from my living room window, I had never climbed before.

After leaving the summit of Baildon Moor we headed down to the road and through the golf course before following a horse training track around to Weecher Reservoir.

Leaving Weecher Reservoir we walked briefly along a very busy road before heading out on the long walk up Rombald‚Äôs Moor, walking first along a wall before crossing through it and walking diagonally away from it towards the path joining from the Dales Way through a boggy section. We pasued here for a brew and to eat our lunch. Pushing onwards we came to the Twelve Apostles stone circle, were we fired off a few shots and admired the view to Drachs. We carried on for about 50m to get a photograph across Wharfedale.

Leaving the path here we headed out to the summit of Rombald‚Äôs Moor through the heather. I believe there is actually a path that runs along the escarpment. After reaching the summit we headed back towards the Dalesway, but dropped off the escarpment earlier and headed diagonally across the Moor to rejoin the path lower down. This proved an error as the ground was very wet in places here. On coming to a cafe we followed the road down into Ilkley. We went to the station to check the times of the train, making the 15:53 train with about 30 seconds to spare. This walk would have been around 10 miles long.

items.title: Foel Goch ‚Äì Arenig
items.content_html: I did enjoy the walking, but there were several things about this walk that really pissed me off. 1. Being accosted by unrestrained dogs at both ends. 2. Trudging through pathless bog. 3. Getting to the top, seeing the youth hostel just the other side of the hill but 30 miles drive away, and a lovely track heading up the hill from the youth hostel. In summary‚Ä¶. do this walk from somewhere other than Pentre-tai-yn-y-cwm. Foel Goch ‚Äì 611m ‚Äì Arenigs¬†

items.title: Moel Ysgyfarnogod and Foel Penolau from the west
items.content_html: Feeling much recovered from my exertions earlier in the week, and having gained much confidence from the day prior, Richard and I decided upon an attempt on the isolated Moel Ysfarnogod behind Llyn Trawsfynydd. Starting at the head of the minor road from Glan-y-wern we followed route 9.2 in the Wales volume of the Nuttalls books. The weather was superb all day, and the only real navigation problem during the day was choosing the point at which to leave the old mine track that leads pretty much to the mountain. As it happened we had chosen the right track, but did question our judgement as we following the track around the south side of the mountain, but ultimately we reached Llyn Du. The route was quite straightforward from here, descending down into the col and then scrambling up onto Foel Penolau and on to its two summits. The scrambling is light, taking an obvious gully to the centre of the the mountain, and pretty much whatever line you like onto the two tops. Much recommended on a nice day, you will have the hill pretty much to yourself as we did.Moel Ysgyfarnogod ‚Äì 623m ‚Äì Rhinogs Foel Penolau ‚Äì 614m ‚Äì Rhinogs

items.title: Tal y Fan and the Great Orme
items.content_html: With me still feeling rubbish we opted for another easy day, taking in the Marilyns of Tal y Fan on the northern side of the Carneddau and Great Orme above Llandudno. The ascent of Tal y Fan was quite straight forward. We parked by Cae Coch, and followed a path through a field to the wall which runs along Tal y Fan, following that over a few false tops to the summit. The ascent of Great Orme was rather pleasant. We parked up by the dry ski slope, and the relatively easy gradient was rather welcome. The views over Conway Bay were first class, and I regretted not having taken the SLR with me.Tal y Fan ‚Äì 610m ‚Äì Carneddau Great Orme ‚Äì 207m ‚Äì Llandudno.

items.title: Traverse of the Carneddau from Pen yr Helgi Du to Yr Elen
items.content_html: The first day of a weeks walking in Wales with Richard, and the first big walk for me since breaking my foot. We parked up at little Tryfan, crossed over the road and climbed up Pen yr Helgi Du. My foot didn‚Äôt enjoy the scramble down and up to Carnedd Llewellyn, my head liked it less so! We descended to Bethesda with a skull collector we met in the wind shelter on Llewelly, taking in Yr Elen along the way. We had intended to get the last bus of the day into Ogwen Valley, but unfortunately that ship had already sailed, so we walked back up as far as a viewpoint near the corner of the road, where we convinced a random Aussie to give us a lift back to the car‚Ä¶Pen yr Helgi Du ‚Äì 833m ‚Äì Carneddau Carnedd Llewelyn ‚Äì 1064m ‚Äì Carneddau Yr Elen ‚Äì 962m ‚Äì Carneddau

items.title: Cat Bells
items.content_html: On our Sunday up in the Lakes Vickie and I decided to walk up Cat Bells, Vickie‚Äôs first Wainwright!!! We drove over to Keswick from St. Bees and parked in the car park at the pencil factory and had a general womble around the town in the morning. In the afternoon we caught the ferry across, having to get off at Brandlehow as the Hawse End landing stage was closed. We wandered along the shore to the bottom of the hill at Hawse End, and ambled up on to the first summit, and along to below the second. There were a few rocky bits that I wouldn‚Äôt fancy dragging my granny up, as AW suggested! I went up over the summit to make sure that it wasn‚Äôt too rocky, which it wasn‚Äôt, so we headed along the ridge dropping down from Hause Gate and back to the ferry at Brandlehow, pausing momentarily to observe the old mine workings which are mostly fenced in. We had to run for the boat both leaving and returning to Keswick, but were lucky to make both sailings. The weather was largely good, and we had an awesome day, the rain holding out till we were back on the boat!

items.content_html: A coach meet with WBMC. The weather never did quite live up to the forecast, although the wind and hail was suffiuce to make Jonathan, myself and Stephen think twice about doing the Cwfry Arete. We shot up to Cwm Cau from Minffordd, up the foxes path, which is a bit of a scree run, and onto the ridge where the strong easterly could be felt. We descended the foxes path to the base of the Cwfry Arete, where we decided the wind was too strong. Point of note ‚Äì if Jonathan tells you a path is ok, beware! From leaving the summit shelter the remainder of the afternoon was characterised by my incessant bout of hic-cups, bouldering on crumbling rock, and drinking on Dollgellau.

items.content_html: A walk with John Edwards, from thew Patterdale coach meet with WBMC. We walked over Arnison Crag and then Birks Fell in very heavy winds on poor snow, and decided that we would not continue over St Sunday Crag. We traversed the side of St Sunday Crag to Grisedale Tarn where we had lunch. John located one of his Geocaches near the brother‚Äôs parting stone ( just a few weeks later he would discover on tied to his windscreen wiper!), and then he located another near Lanty‚Äôs Tarn on our return to Glenridding. Whilst I was enjoying a pint in the Traveller‚Äôs Rest, John was locating a webcam cache. Only three letters spring to mind O‚Ä¶C‚Ä¶D‚Ä¶‚Ä¶‚Ä¶.!

items.content_html: I was picked up early in the morning by Andy on route to picking up Ian and Paul. We had opted to climb up the Table Top Direct Route (VD) on the Cwfry Arete, following the Grade 3 Scramble from the Table Top to the ridge. It was a really good day and climb, the weather was awesome, and a nutter soloed past us on what can only be described as very loose rock! I also did a fair amount of leading, including an awkward bridging pitch, and was very happy with progress so far. We didn‚Äôt get off the climb until after 5pm, so we didn‚Äôt make it to the summit of Cadair Idris, and arrived back at the car about 7pm.

items.title: Climbing at The Roaches
items.content_html: Climbing with Andy again. Left at about 9am, and was climbing for about 10:30ish. The weather forecast was abysmal for the club‚Äôs coach meet to the Nantlle ridge area, so we opted for The Roaches.First climb was Maud‚Äôs Garden, a nice VD with a climb up the slab to a pronounced ledge, followed by a chimney move near the top, and then a move back out onto the face to climb for a further metre or so.The second climb was Aqua, a VS 4c which Andy has led previously, and on this occasion we decided to top rope. This commences with a climb up the corner of the slab up to an overhang above. The key to the overhang is to layback to the left, with the right hand in a very good hold. This should permit the right leg to move up onto a good foot hold, and the left hand above the right hand. The climb up the slab is relatively straight forward thereafter.Our final climb of the day was Rooster, a D that was to become my first lead. The first half of the climb is a smear up the slab to a large ledge. As this was very green, I opted to use the adjacent gully up to this point, as it was not possible to place any protection, and we were already a good 10m above the floor before commencing climbing. From the ledge the climb heads up the large crack to the left side of the face.Immediately placing a wire in the roof of the overhanging section, I then levered myself up to the final problem. There is a very large crack, which ultimately I used for an arm jam. The main difficulty is that the wall bulges outwards, and the foot placements here are not great. Committing to the move, I was soon on top and bringing Andy up to an audience.Can‚Äôt climb outdoors for a couple of weeks now ‚Äì so back to Wolf Mountain Unitl the next time
items.content_text:
Climbing with Andy again. Left at about 9am, and was climbing for about 10:30ish. The weather forecast was abysmal for the club‚Äôs coach meet to the Nantlle ridge area, so we opted for The Roaches.

First climb was Maud‚Äôs Garden, a nice VD with a climb up the slab to a pronounced ledge, followed by a chimney move near the top, and then a move back out onto the face to climb for a further metre or so.

The second climb was Aqua, a VS 4c which Andy has led previously, and on this occasion we decided to top rope. This commences with a climb up the corner of the slab up to an overhang above. The key to the overhang is to layback to the left, with the right hand in a very good hold. This should permit the right leg to move up onto a good foot hold, and the left hand above the right hand. The climb up the slab is relatively straight forward thereafter.

Our final climb of the day was Rooster, a D that was to become my first lead. The first half of the climb is a smear up the slab to a large ledge. As this was very green, I opted to use the adjacent gully up to this point, as it was not possible to place any protection, and we were already a good 10m above the floor before commencing climbing. From the ledge the climb heads up the large crack to the left side of the face.

Immediately placing a wire in the roof of the overhanging section, I then levered myself up to the final problem. There is a very large crack, which ultimately I used for an arm jam. The main difficulty is that the wall bulges outwards, and the foot placements here are not great. Committing to the move, I was soon on top and bringing Andy up to an audience.

Can‚Äôt climb outdoors for a couple of weeks now ‚Äì so back to Wolf Mountain

Unitl the next time

items.title: Climbing on Milestone Buttress and Little Tryfan
items.content_html: Had discussed the idea of climbing this weekend with Andy earlier in the week, weather dependent, and until I received a voicemail on Friday night at 10pm, I had thought that it wasn‚Äôt going to happen. I left the party I was at around midnight, and headed to the 24 hour ASDA to get some healthy hill food (Mars Bars). After packing the sack for the day, I probably got to sleep at about 0130 for a 0630 start.Made it to Andy‚Äôs in time for an 0730 depart, and headed out to Ogwen via the cafe with a bookshop above it in Llangollen. We did two multipitches on Milestone Buttress ‚Äì Rowan Route and Pulpit Route, both Diffs, before heading to Little Tryfan to do a couple of routes. The weather was really good all day, and we got in over 1000ft of climbing, Andy over 1500 ft as he twice soloed Crack 1 on Little Tryfan whilst I played about on the boulders nearby.The day went really well, lets hope its a precursor for the season ahead. Did a bit of gear shopping in Betsy before grabbing a bag of chips and driving home, and watching a perfect lunar eclipse.

items.title: Climb of the Fiacaill Ridge on Cairn Gorm
items.content_html: The perfect day. Parking at the ski centre Andy, Ian and I headed over to the Fiacaill ridge between Coire an t-Sneachda and Coire an Lochain, and I volunteered for the first turn at carrying the rope. The ridge is largely a walk up, but climaxing in a grade I/II winter climb, dependent upon the route chosen. Arriving at the climb we missed the start out to avoide a couple of large roped parties, but quickly climbed back up to the ridge. Once on the ridge we battled our way up opnto the Cairn Gorm plateau, with bright blue skies and white ground we didn‚Äôt care too much about the wind. We ambled across the plateau to Cairngorm and returned via the ski area! On getting back to the car, I realised that nobody else had taken their turn at carrying the rope Grrrrr!!!!!In the pub that evening Steve Clarke took great pleasure in pointing out that we had missed the grade II section of the climb blah di blah di blah. Thought this was quite funny coming from somebody who had ascended the Grade 6 North Face of the Cairn Gorm Mountain Furnicular!!!!!

items.title: Attempt on Creag Meagaidh
items.content_html: Parking at Aberarder, the day looked initially so promising, but turned sour. The cliffs on Creag Meagaidh are fantastic, had I taken my technical axes I would have attempted one of two gullies, and next time I go to Meagaidh I will be going to climb. We kcked steps up to the top of the window, reaching within half a kilometer and 200m climb of our target, but with very high winds and hail decided to turn around. We had a practice of ice axe breaking on the way back down, but 15km was a bloody long way to walk just for that! However, to be fair the view of the cliffs made the walk in worthwhile and left me feeling inspired.

items.title: Ascent of Sgor Gaoith
items.content_html: Ian and I headed out to Auchlean in Glen Feshie, and headed up over Carn Ban Mor onto Sgor Gaoith, returnuing the same way. Above about 900m we were in whiteout conditions, and to obtain Sgor Gaoith we had to return to Carn Ban Mor and once again set the bearing. Finally we reached the top with a little help from the old GPS! We returned via Smiffy‚Äôs fish and chip shop in Aviemore!

items.title: Ascent of Beinn Teallach
items.content_html: A good day out with John, Paul, Chris and Ian. We opted to head out west for Beinn Teallach, and possibly to complete the horseshoe including Beinn a‚Äô Chaorainn. As it turned out we headed straight up Beinn Teallach, and returned the same way. The weather forecast had been horrendous, and our group was the only one to attempt 3000ft. We returned to the car to a chorus of ‚Äúyoul never stand at 3000 ft on a day like this!‚Äù and ‚Äúyou‚Äôll never get a cloud free view from a 3000 ft Mountain on a day like this. Despite protestations later, we never did quite manage to obtain the finest bagels in all the land. The most interesting point of the day was Paul vomiting Talisker everywhere and having to retire early with John, it made a nice change for it not to be me!
items.content_text: A good day out with John, Paul, Chris and Ian. We opted to head out west for Beinn Teallach, and possibly to complete the horseshoe including Beinn a‚Äô Chaorainn. As it turned out we headed straight up Beinn Teallach, and returned the same way. The weather forecast had been horrendous, and our group was the only one to attempt 3000ft. We returned to the car to a chorus of ‚Äúyoul never stand at 3000 ft on a day like this!‚Äù and ‚Äúyou‚Äôll never get a cloud free view from a 3000 ft Mountain on a day like this. Despite protestations later, we never did quite manage to obtain the finest bagels in all the land. The most interesting point of the day was Paul vomiting Talisker everywhere and having to retire early with John, it made a nice change for it not to be me!

items.title: A circuit on the Eastern Carneddau
items.content_html: On the coach with West Bromwich MC, I was pretty tired after an intensive Saturday afternoon climbing at Wolf Mountain. I struggled more than I would have liked, but it was the first major mountain walk since my return from injury carrying and wearing full winter gear. Dropped off at Capel, a group of about eight of us headed up the Ogwen Road, I would spend most of the day with Andy and Darren, and headed off on the track passing through Tal-y-waun. From here the ridge of Pen Llithrig-y-wrach is very obvious. I was already fading a little, but made good pace to the top, and enjoyed a rest waiting for the others. It was here that Bob made contact with somebody on Whernside with his radio, the first time I have known him succesfully contact anybody. I descended very quickly to Llyn Cowlyd, but decided to wait here and join the slower half of the group. This was a good call, as the ascent of Creigiau Gleision was very arduous, and one did not feel too well. On attaining the ridge we broke for food befor visiting the north top, then the true summit, and descending via Craiglwyn and Craig Wen. The latter of which was notable, as we had to scramble to its summit, although it would have been possible not to do so had we felt so inclined. The walk out was long, and I was glad that the Bryn Tyrch was shut, as we did not have time for a pint, arriving less than a minute before the coach!

I descended very quickly to Llyn Cowlyd, but decided to wait here and join the slower half of the group. On attaining the ridge we broke for food befor visiting the north top, then the true summit, and descending via Craiglwyn and Craig Wen. The latter of which was notable, as we had to scramble to its summit, although it would have been possible not to do so had we felt so inclined.

The walk out was long, and I was glad that the Bryn Tyrch was shut, as we did not have time for a pint, arriving less than a minute before the coach!

items.title: Mynydd Troed and Mynydd Llangorse from Llangorse
items.content_html: The club’s New Year meet was very good socially, although the weather was a bit of a washout! We headed north in a ciruit from Llangorse through very muddy fields and in heavy rain and high winds. We returned back over Mynydd Troed, and a select few of us over Mynydd Llangorse as opposed to the baggers road! The weather actually lifted a little over the second peak, although we never really gained a view.

items.title: Ice Climbing at the Ice Factor
items.content_html: An afternoon ice climbing at the Ice Factor in Kinlochleven, my only achievement during a tonsilitis ridden Hogmanay in Fort William. Accompanied by Chris Dean and Steve Clark, the highlight being a 12m corner climb upto the roof and slightly overhanging, as depiceted in the bridging photographs.

items.title: Smash and grab ascent of Allt-fawr
items.content_html: Despite the fact that I didn’t go to Elbrus, I was invited on the Elbrus Reunion, which was a very beery weekend. The photographs show a smash and grab raid on Allt-fawr on the Saturday - as the drinkers amongst us were a little dishevelled by their 6am heads down. After Fred had finished throwing up over a wall on the Crimea Pass we headed straight up to Allt-fawr following the ridge along. We had great views from the summit, despite the overcast weather. We returned via a similiar route, but descended below the ridge to gain some variation.

items.title: Ascent of Bredon Hill
items.content_html: Had a really good day out with Richard and Jo. Starting out by the phone box at Bredon’s Norton we walked around the church and onto the open fields by a well disguised right of way! Following the track up onto the ridge we passed few on the way. The weather was perfect at the outset, but quickly deteriorated, giving quite a buffeting while eating lunch in the summit earthworks.We walked too far along the ridge, and retraced our steps to a place where we could head down to the landrover track below. Finally reaching the track we followed a private road through a small forest and followed the track through Woollas Hall and St. Catherine’s Farm to the junction with the village where we turned right to become reacquainted with the car!
items.content_text:
Had a really good day out with Richard and Jo. Starting out by the phone box at Bredon's Norton we walked around the church and onto the open fields by a well disguised right of way! Following the track up onto the ridge we passed few on the way. The weather was perfect at the outset, but quickly deteriorated, giving quite a buffeting while eating lunch in the summit earthworks.

We walked too far along the ridge, and retraced our steps to a place where we could head down to the landrover track below. Finally reaching the track we followed a private road through a small forest and followed the track through Woollas Hall and St. Catherine's Farm to the junction with the village where we turned right to become reacquainted with the car!

items.title: Ascent of Loughrigg Fell
items.content_html: Me, Claire and Sarah parked up at Skelwith Bridge, and initially struggled to fing the track through the fields up to Loughrigg Tarn, it commences directly opposite the entrance to the Talbot Inn. We headed out to the NW corner of Loughrigg and picked up a very good track onto the Fell itself, walking over it in a SW direction, hitting the road near Ashley Green. We then walked back up to Skelwith Bridge along the pathless road, almost getting knocked over by a police car on the sharpest of the bends.

items.title: Ascents of Hard Knott and Whitfell
items.content_html: Accompanied by John Hipwood, Mike Nicholls and Simon on a day of varied weather to include hail, snow, rain and sunshine. We parked at Cockley Beck for Hard Knott, walking up the pass, before using Hardknott Gill to guide us up between Hard Knott and Border End and then heading over to the summit. We parked up at Old Hall Farm above Millbrow for Whitfell, heading up the road to Bigert Mire, and along the bridleway thereafter. We took a direct line off the track onto Whitfell, and returned the same way.

items.title: Ascent of Snowdon
items.content_html: With Richard, an ascent of Snowdon via the Pyg track, and a descent down the Llanberis path, which Richard had not bagged before! This was followed by a rather long wait in the pub for everybody else to come back!

items.title: Traverse of Fan Brycheiniog
items.content_html: A traverse of the ridge starting at Bwlch Cerrig Duon, heading up over Bwlch Giedd and then onto Fan Hir. We then reversed back to the bwlch and followed the edge of the cliff out to Fan Brycheiniog, Fan Foel, Picws Du and Waun Lefrith before heading out to Garreg Las and Carreg yr Ogof. Dropping down then below Waun Lefrith we traced our route back under the cliffs to the car, arriving back at sunset.

items.title: Traverse of the Carneddau from Ogwen to Aber
items.content_html: Had a really good day out today, despite the recent injury setbacks i’m now confident that my excuse for a knee is on the mend. Opted not to go climbing on Tryfan due to the physio’s advice, but I deliberately didn’t ask if I could go walking!Much of the route is discussed the page linked below, the only noticeable difference being the descent into Aber via Llwytmor and Aber Falls as opposed to via Drum.I felt that we were quite lucky with the weather, having a view all day long. Towards the end of the day the wind really picked up, being as strong as anything I have experienced in winter Scotland, if not perhaps a little stronger!I opted to assist Mike with the led walk as opposed to attempting any of the longer variants, I didn’t feel any more than an occasional twinge in the knee all day long. I don’t anticipate going out again until early november.See also the page from my last traverse of the Carneddau.
items.content_text:
Had a really good day out today, despite the recent injury setbacks i'm now confident that my excuse for a knee is on the mend. Opted not to go climbing on Tryfan due to the physio's advice, but I deliberately didn't ask if I could go walking!

Much of the route is discussed the page linked below, the only noticeable difference being the descent into Aber via Llwytmor and Aber Falls as opposed to via Drum.

I felt that we were quite lucky with the weather, having a view all day long. Towards the end of the day the wind really picked up, being as strong as anything I have experienced in winter Scotland, if not perhaps a little stronger!

I opted to assist Mike with the led walk as opposed to attempting any of the longer variants, I didn't feel any more than an occasional twinge in the knee all day long. I don't anticipate going out again until early november.

See also the page from my last traverse of the Carneddau.

items.title: Ascent of Yr Aran
items.content_html: With Jo, Sally and Richard ascended Yr Aran via its East Ridge and descended via its north ridge to Snowdon’s South col. In and out on the Watkin path from and to the hut.
items.content_text: With Jo, Sally and Richard ascended Yr Aran via its East Ridge and descended via its north ridge to Snowdon's South col. In and out on the Watkin path from and to the hut.

items.title: A circuit of Elidir Fawr from the north
items.content_html: A northern circuit of Elidir Fawr, commencing near Deinolen, heading up onto Carnedd y Filiast, following the ridge round to Mynydd Perfedd and then ascending somewhat steeply up onto Elidir Fawr. We descended straight down the screes and over Elidir Fach to the quarry road below.

items.title: Ascent of Moel y Dyniewyd
items.content_html: Arrived at the hut with Richard early on the Saturday. Jo and Sally failed to arrive, and noting that Yr Aran was in the cloud, which Richard wanted to ‘bag’ we headed up the track to Beddgelert, and left it for Moel y Dyniewyd. Despite it not being mapped there is a very good path over to the hill, although there are several places in which it is precipitously steep. We found a few disused copper minus to which access could still be gained, and then headed back to the hut along Llyn Dinas.

items.title: Hills around Welshpool
items.content_html: I had been suffering from a poorly knee of late. I believe that I am suffering from a condition known as ‘runner’s knee’. This is essentially a precursor to chondromalacia and caused by a disbalance between strength of hamstrings and quadriceps. Seeing as though my quads have wasted I’m currently trying to rebuild them! However, when Andy asked if I wanted to accompany him on another marilyn bagging day in his attempt to complete Dawson’s list, I couldn’t resist, although today was a tad more strenuous than I had banked on.The first hill of the day was Moel y Golfa above Middletown. We parked near a house at Garreg Bank, the path actually commences from their driveway by a sign instructing you not to block their access route. We ascended very steeply through trees to gain a lovely ridge with a rather large memorial on the summit. We descended by the same route, although it was pretty steep, and I wouldn’t particular enjoy it in the wet.The second top of the day was Beacon Ring on Long Mountain. This was a short walk in from where we parked the car near Short Cross. We followed an access track to the foot of the radio masts. Finding the trig point was somewhat more problematic as it was buried in the forest.We proceeded next to Caeliber Isaf, battling our way through barbed fencing from near White Hall Farm. The bull beyond the summit didn’t appreciate my bright red Berghaus base layer, and so we made a rather quick retreat back over the fence.Stingwern Hill was particularly nice, if somewhat short. We parked up in a gateway north east of Llidiardu, and took a short walk through sheep filled fields to the trigpoint, returning the same way.If Stingwern Hill was easy, Upper Park was more of a slog. Parking up near Trefnant Hall in a layby, we headed up a very obvious track into the forest and out to the open hillside above. Heading back into the forest to find the summit I seem to recall avoiding an area of gorse. The summit area is actually in the field adjacent to the forest, and we returned via the fields, not re-entering the forest, and coming out at the start point.Y Golfa was more challenging, certainly the ferns were higher than me! Parking up on the A458 after a junction with a local road, we headed on up the path and then battered our way through the ferns on the way from it to the summit from where we observed some people attempting to play golf with little success!We parked rather cheekily in a farmyard near Grwnamlwg to ascend Allt y Main via a forest track to a walk up the ridge, and descended via the same route. The forest track was irritating and seemed to drag with lots of recently conducted felling works.We parked at the end of a local road for Rhailgwn. We walked along the landrover track, and ascended to the eastern edge of the trees. The cloud had dropped considerably, and I had left my coat in the car! Attempting to descend through the fire break we discovered it to be full of gorse, and had to enter and descend through the forest. We dropped out almost opposite where we had parked!Mynydd y-briw was even more embarrasing. At the end of the road there is a house with no lay bys on the road. Not fancing the extra 100m of ascent we turned aroung in their driveway, parked on a ramp on the garden, and walked from there, took about 5 minutes in total to the top and back!
items.content_text:
I had been suffering from a poorly knee of late. I believe that I am suffering from a condition known as 'runner's knee'. This is essentially a precursor to chondromalacia and caused by a disbalance between strength of hamstrings and quadriceps. Seeing as though my quads have wasted I'm currently trying to rebuild them! However, when Andy asked if I wanted to accompany him on another marilyn bagging day in his attempt to complete Dawson's list, I couldn't resist, although today was a tad more strenuous than I had banked on.

The first hill of the day was Moel y Golfa above Middletown. We parked near a house at Garreg Bank, the path actually commences from their driveway by a sign instructing you not to block their access route. We ascended very steeply through trees to gain a lovely ridge with a rather large memorial on the summit. We descended by the same route, although it was pretty steep, and I wouldn't particular enjoy it in the wet.

The second top of the day was Beacon Ring on Long Mountain. This was a short walk in from where we parked the car near Short Cross. We followed an access track to the foot of the radio masts. Finding the trig point was somewhat more problematic as it was buried in the forest.

We proceeded next to Caeliber Isaf, battling our way through barbed fencing from near White Hall Farm. The bull beyond the summit didn't appreciate my bright red Berghaus base layer, and so we made a rather quick retreat back over the fence.

Stingwern Hill was particularly nice, if somewhat short. We parked up in a gateway north east of Llidiardu, and took a short walk through sheep filled fields to the trigpoint, returning the same way.

If Stingwern Hill was easy, Upper Park was more of a slog. Parking up near Trefnant Hall in a layby, we headed up a very obvious track into the forest and out to the open hillside above. Heading back into the forest to find the summit I seem to recall avoiding an area of gorse. The summit area is actually in the field adjacent to the forest, and we returned via the fields, not re-entering the forest, and coming out at the start point.

Y Golfa was more challenging, certainly the ferns were higher than me! Parking up on the A458 after a junction with a local road, we headed on up the path and then battered our way through the ferns on the way from it to the summit from where we observed some people attempting to play golf with little success!

We parked rather cheekily in a farmyard near Grwnamlwg to ascend Allt y Main via a forest track to a walk up the ridge, and descended via the same route. The forest track was irritating and seemed to drag with lots of recently conducted felling works.

We parked at the end of a local road for Rhailgwn. We walked along the landrover track, and ascended to the eastern edge of the trees. The cloud had dropped considerably, and I had left my coat in the car! Attempting to descend through the fire break we discovered it to be full of gorse, and had to enter and descend through the forest. We dropped out almost opposite where we had parked!

Mynydd y-briw was even more embarrasing. At the end of the road there is a house with no lay bys on the road. Not fancing the extra 100m of ascent we turned aroung in their driveway, parked on a ramp on the garden, and walked from there, took about 5 minutes in total to the top and back!

items.title: Ascents of Driesh and Mayar
items.content_html: We didn’t get going until about 10:30 irnoically despite our rather tactical sleepover at the fantastic Glen Clova Hotel the evening prior. Ascended Driesh via the very steep Scorrie, headed over the plateau to Mayar, and descended along the Fee Burn back to the car near Glen Doll Youth Hostel. The Jock’s road was apparent at times, and this was poignant as I had just read “The Black Cloud” which detailed a group who had strayed from the path near Tolmount, and would ultimately perish in the nearby White Water.

items.title: Ascent of Mount Keen
items.content_html: With Andy and Richard I headed off early on the Saturday morning for Scotland. We parked up at Invermark after a fantastic drive up, and was walking for 9:30. We headed up the Mounth Path to Mount Keen, which turned out to be Richard’s first Munro, and returned via the same way. Although the walk is rather dull, it does profer fantastic views over to Lochnagar. We bemused some tourist prior to our departure by soloing the Queen’s Well.

items.title: Ascent of the Stiperstones
items.content_html: An ascent of Stiperstones from Stiperstones Inn, where we had eaten and slept the night before. Enjoyed playing about on the tors whilst Mike, John and Sue watched.

items.title: The Clee Hills, Caer Caradoc and Pole Bank
items.content_html: A failed attempt to complete the Shropshire 6, precipitated by arriving at the pub in Bridges 10 minutes before England vs. Portugal kicked of!!!! Fantastic weather throughout.

items.title: Ascent of Pontesbury Hill
items.content_html: Followed the path up the hill from the small car park for the nature reserve. Heading up to the hill we then descended, and played about with the slabs for some time prior to returning home via a pub and an England game.

items.title: Ascent of the Wrekin
items.content_html: Walked over the Wrekin with Richard from the carpark nearest the motorway, and returned via a path the run along the flank of the hill to make a nice circuit.
items.content_text: Walked over the Wrekin with Richard from the carpark nearest the motorway, and returned via a path the run along the flank of the hill to make a nice circuit.

items.title: Ascent of Pole Bank - The Long Mynd
items.content_html: A circuit of the Long Mynd from the Cardingmill Valley. Accompanied by Jo and Richard we ascended from here, headed over to Pole Bank, and descended to Little Stretton via various minor tops, walking back up the road to the car.

items.title: Lambrigg Fell and Grayrigg Forest
items.content_html: Jumping off the coach early at J37 of the M6, John Mike and I were on the summit of Lambrigg Fell before the others had even got to Patterdale. In the sun all day we looked on throughout at the cloud covering Helvellyn, and basked in the wisdom of our choice. We also had several good pints in a nice pub at Tebay village before being picked up at the Penrith junction.

items.title: Ascent of Snowdon
items.content_html: An ascent of Snowdon up the Llanberis path with university colleagues. The weather was abysmal, although the food in the Bryn Tyrch was fantastic.

items.title: Chamonix Weekend - Col du Midi & Mer de Glace
items.content_html: We flew out on the Friday afternoon, and consumed far too much lager in a dodgy Mexican restaurant near the Hotel Louvre in which we stayed. On the Saturday we were turned back by snow conditions on Mont Blanc du Tacul which was clearly waiting to avalanche. On saturday we climbed ice on the Mer de Glace above Montenvers, and on the Sunday we flew home. Dave spent ,most of the weekend doing a ‘killer tomato impression from wearing his beanie hat on the Col du Midi.

items.content_html: Enjoy the photographs. The routes up each of these hills are fairly obvious with no real access issues. The parking is equally trouble free. I’m not counting….but i’m on 97 marilyns now!!!!!Wentwood, Garth Hill, Craig yr Allt, Mynydd Machen, Mynydd y Lan, Mynydd Twyn-Glas, Ruardean Hill, May Hill, Garway Hill

items.title: Climbing Weekend at Stanage
items.content_html: The club’s annual climbing weekend at Stanage on the May Bank Holiday weekend. Followed by the routine ramble over to Burbage and back with Mr. Eadon.

items.title: Ascents of Sugarloaf and Bryn Arw
items.content_html: I picked Richard up on the Sunday morning, and parked up at Porth-y-part below Sugar Loaf. We ascended up the long ridge of Deri and onto Sugar Loaf, and descended down Rholben creating a nice circuit. With plenty of time to spare we opted to battle through the gorse onto Bryn Arw. Ouch…

items.title: The Worcestershire Beacon
items.content_html: I picked Richard up on the Sunday morning and headed off to the Malvern Hills. Starting at End Hill we summited each and every bump on the way to the Worcestershire Beacon, descended to a pub at its foot, and then crossed back over the hills to the car park. A rather pleasant stroll…..enjoy us pictures.

A rather pleasant stroll.....enjoy us pictures.

items.title: Ascent of Shining Tor, Gun and The Cloud
items.content_html: On the sunday we headed first to Shining Tor, which we ascended from the Cat and Fiddle in somewhat murky weather, before heading off to Gun, which was a stroll across a field from a layby on the road near Haddon (10 minutes!) and then to The Cloud froma carpark on the Timbersbrook Road. The Cloud was a great little hill, with good views over Congleton and towards Shining Tor, and a mirage of interesting inscriptions on the summit rocks. This was also a popular location for local model airoplane enthusiasts we seemed to multiply by the second.Many thanks go to John for organising a great weekend, to Sue for hosting it, and to t’others for the good company. Cheers.

items.title: Raw Head, Penycloddiau, Cyrn-y-Brain and Moel y Gamelin
items.content_html: I drove up to Sue’s at about 8am to meet up with Su, John, Simon, and Mike Nicholls. This was an achievement insofar as that it was the day following my birthday, but I had taken a relativelt early night.We drove first out to Penycloddiau, however a closed road diverted us past Raw Head, which John had scheduled for the next day. Stopping off here we shot up the Sandstone Trail, at the base of which is a layby, took in the hill and its cave, and returned to the car before 10am!Setting off again we stopped at Penycloddiau, the walk to the summit of which was a fair length from the car park to the South East end of the ridge, and it was quite cold at this point. Being fairly clagged in we did not get much of a view, however Moel Arthur across the way looked worth exploring at some point.We next heade for the Horseshoe Pass above Llangollen, where we first ascended Cyrn-y-Brain, in cold claggy weather, walking as far as the ruins of Sir Watkin’s Tower. On our return to the pass the weather brightened considerably, and we enjoyed a rather pleasant stroll up Moel y Gamelin, with decent views.

items.title: Ascent of Sharp Haw
items.content_html: We left West Bromwich at the usual time, but the weather worsened, and there was ice on the floor at Charnock Richard. I think after this point we were travelling northbound at most at 40mph. The A65 hadn’t been gritted between the M6 and Gargrave. When the traffic infront caused us to stop we were unable to regain traction, and twice had to push the coach up a hill.Finally arriving in Skipton at 13:30 we were able to take in just the one hill, Sharp Haw, which large entails a pleasant stroll through fields. Much of the forest indicated on the map has been felled, and so access was no problem, with the exception of the snow!

items.title: A Traverse of Beinn Sgulaird from Druimavuic
items.content_html: I felt absolutely awful on the sunday, feeling nauseous before even leaving the car! I decided that if I didn’t climb I would only have to sit in the car all day, still feeling like crap. As appealing as 6 hours reading a Fire Risk Assessment manual may appear to some, I was nonetheless unimpressed with that option. In part this was fashioned by the fact that the weather looked fantastic, and I was still bitter about missing the super weather enjoyed by others on the Friday at Newtonmore.We had decided to find an alternative approach route on the basis of our views of Beinn Sgulaird the previous day, and opted for the traverse from Druimavuic. We headed up a good track which you can follow to about 600m, and I had decided to see how far up it I could get without throwing up! After about 200m of climbing we came to a very obvious fault line that led straight up on to the ridge, and opted to go up that way instead, as it was probably easier terrain than going straight up the face of Meall Garbh.Up until this point I had been debating turning around every 10 minutes or so. When we reached the bealach, and I discovered that we were at 520m, I knew that I would not be turning around, and before long we were on the first granite top on the ridge. I probably did not know about the drops inbetween the tops, or had chose to ignore what I had seen of them the day previous. In all there is probably about 1100m of climb on this route with two very large descents and ascents before reaching the summit proper. I was appeased though by the fantastic views, and the terrain was superb.The ice bothered us a little on the descent, but not majorly so, and before long we were back in Glen Creran. I had felt ok up until that point, but felt awful trudging back to the car from here, and it was only really when we reached the M6 that I stopped feeling unbelievably sick. I was thankful when Andy run out of diesel and had to stop at Stafford services, as I had been crossing my legs since we passed Hamilton services considerably earlier in the evening.

items.title: Ascent of Beinn Fhionnlaidh from Elleric
items.content_html: Leaving Birmingham at 03:30 on the Saturday morning, myself, Andy and Smithy headed up to Glen Etive in search of winter conditions. Clocking -10¬∞C near Annandale Services, it was a cold journey up. Eventually we arrives at Elleric, and after a debate decided to ascend Beinn Fhinnlaidh that day, and Beinn Sgulaird on the Sunday. I felt pretty rough on the Saturday, but not as bad as I would on the Sunday!The weather had been clear all the way up, but as soon as we stopped at Elleric it began to cloud in, although throughout the day the weather was pretty good to be fair. Passing the farm at Glenure we made straight for the open grassy banks of Leac Bharainn that led up to Beinn Fhionnlaidh, not really reching much snow until about 700m.I think it is fair to say that we all decided that Beinn Sgulaird looked pretty precipituous from this direction, and this resulted in our decision not to climb it from Elleric the following day. Thew weather was fairly kind to us, and before long we were on the summit partaking in lunch. On the way down, as usual, it was I who fell into a bog, the problem of mud on ones trousers being resolved by a short paddle in the River Ure!Setting off from Elleric we visited first Appin, the strangely named Benderloch, and finally Connell before finding a bed and breakfast and a pub in which to eat.
items.content_text:
Leaving Birmingham at 03:30 on the Saturday morning, myself, Andy and Smithy headed up to Glen Etive in search of winter conditions. Clocking -10¬∞C near Annandale Services, it was a cold journey up. Eventually we arrives at Elleric, and after a debate decided to ascend Beinn Fhinnlaidh that day, and Beinn Sgulaird on the Sunday. I felt pretty rough on the Saturday, but not as bad as I would on the Sunday!

The weather had been clear all the way up, but as soon as we stopped at Elleric it began to cloud in, although throughout the day the weather was pretty good to be fair. Passing the farm at Glenure we made straight for the open grassy banks of Leac Bharainn that led up to Beinn Fhionnlaidh, not really reching much snow until about 700m.

I think it is fair to say that we all decided that Beinn Sgulaird looked pretty precipituous from this direction, and this resulted in our decision not to climb it from Elleric the following day. Thew weather was fairly kind to us, and before long we were on the summit partaking in lunch. On the way down, as usual, it was I who fell into a bog, the problem of mud on ones trousers being resolved by a short paddle in the River Ure!

Setting off from Elleric we visited first Appin, the strangely named Benderloch, and finally Connell before finding a bed and breakfast and a pub in which to eat.

items.title: Ascent of Braeriach through the Chalamain Gap
items.content_html: One of my main ambitions for this week (as it had been the previous year) was to ‘do’ Braeriach. On this occasion I was to have an attempt with Tim and Ian.Ian had sworn me to secrecy the previous evening to restrict the size of the group, and at breakfast I was insisting that I was having a rest day despite having the salopettes and boots on, and having been seen by at least 10 people putting the sac in the car!!!We didn’t leave as early as we had intended, and this did have a bearing on the rest of the day. Parking up at the Sugarbowl about 0915 we proceeded along the footpath that ultimately leads to the Chalamain Gap. The footpath on this side is rather good, and the sun was out over the northern corries. However I was feeling rather jaded by this point in the week, and did have concerns about my ability to complete this walk, at this point.The walk in was rather better than the photographs suggest, although with the sun over Cairngorm it spoilt any pictures taken. The gap was both dry and free from snow, and we were soon heartbreakingly descending into the Lairig Ghru.Crossing the burn we were soon ascending along the long ridge of Sron na Lairig, and before long into the cloud. The wind was ferocious as was the spindrift it created. The speeds were gusting between 40mph and 60mph, and made progress exceedingly difficult. Arriving at the first top on Sron na Lairig at 12:55, I suggested that we should turn around as we would clearly not summit by 13:15, which was the turn around time that I had in mind. It was decided to pursue, and we spent a considerable amount of time cramponing up, immediately after a previous long break in which Ian had donned an extra layer.Heading over Sron na Lairig we soon found ourselves at the col below Braeriach. With visibility drifting in and out, I knew that we were not too far away, and when it was suggested that we turned around here, it was my vote that decided that we should continue, and I chose to do so as I was now quite happily walking away in crampons, and really felt just that little too close to turn around.We summitted Braeriach at about 14:00, only knowing that we had done so when we began to descend quite steeply. Reversing we found the cairn, and carefully made our way down, myself more on instinct than the precision of Ian and Tim, but between us we found the route fairly well. Our footprints from ascent had been entirely obliterated by the spindrift.The spindrift cleared as we descended, but only intermittently, before finally clearing at about 900m. We kept the crampons on far too long, only taking them off when we next paused at the col above the crossing of the Lairig Ghru. The numerous falls on the way contributing to another sore knee!!!! I was concerned by the 20 minutes spent here as I desparately wanted to get through the Chalamain Gap before dark, knowing that there would now be snow in it.I set a good pace up the hill to the gap, and noted that I felt as fit as I had prior to my 3000s attempt in the summer for the first time since. We cleared the gap whilst it was still in good light, and indeed did not require the head torch to reach the car.On the Thursday I felt that my right knee was very sore and immediately abandoned my plans to walk every day. I went to Aviemore and then Inverness with Andy Brown, procuring Butterfield’s ‘High Mountains’ a book called ‘The Black Cloud’ which details Scottish mountain accidents and is absolutely fantastic, in addition to a new pair of Marmot ‘Borealis’ gloves. I was delighted to discover that as I have tiny hands I required child size gloves at half the price of the adult’s!!!!On the friday I also did not walk, and it turned out to be a fabulous day. I regretted this decision, as my knee felt ok after a brisk stroll up the road, but with retrospect it was the right decision. I’m hoping that a couple of weeks rest will allow it to heal sufficiently.
items.content_text:
One of my main ambitions for this week (as it had been the previous year) was to 'do' Braeriach. On this occasion I was to have an attempt with Tim and Ian.

Ian had sworn me to secrecy the previous evening to restrict the size of the group, and at breakfast I was insisting that I was having a rest day despite having the salopettes and boots on, and having been seen by at least 10 people putting the sac in the car!!!

We didn't leave as early as we had intended, and this did have a bearing on the rest of the day. Parking up at the Sugarbowl about 0915 we proceeded along the footpath that ultimately leads to the Chalamain Gap. The footpath on this side is rather good, and the sun was out over the northern corries. However I was feeling rather jaded by this point in the week, and did have concerns about my ability to complete this walk, at this point.

The walk in was rather better than the photographs suggest, although with the sun over Cairngorm it spoilt any pictures taken. The gap was both dry and free from snow, and we were soon heartbreakingly descending into the Lairig Ghru.

Crossing the burn we were soon ascending along the long ridge of Sron na Lairig, and before long into the cloud. The wind was ferocious as was the spindrift it created. The speeds were gusting between 40mph and 60mph, and made progress exceedingly difficult. Arriving at the first top on Sron na Lairig at 12:55, I suggested that we should turn around as we would clearly not summit by 13:15, which was the turn around time that I had in mind. It was decided to pursue, and we spent a considerable amount of time cramponing up, immediately after a previous long break in which Ian had donned an extra layer.

Heading over Sron na Lairig we soon found ourselves at the col below Braeriach. With visibility drifting in and out, I knew that we were not too far away, and when it was suggested that we turned around here, it was my vote that decided that we should continue, and I chose to do so as I was now quite happily walking away in crampons, and really felt just that little too close to turn around.

We summitted Braeriach at about 14:00, only knowing that we had done so when we began to descend quite steeply. Reversing we found the cairn, and carefully made our way down, myself more on instinct than the precision of Ian and Tim, but between us we found the route fairly well. Our footprints from ascent had been entirely obliterated by the spindrift.

The spindrift cleared as we descended, but only intermittently, before finally clearing at about 900m. We kept the crampons on far too long, only taking them off when we next paused at the col above the crossing of the Lairig Ghru. The numerous falls on the way contributing to another sore knee!!!! I was concerned by the 20 minutes spent here as I desparately wanted to get through the Chalamain Gap before dark, knowing that there would now be snow in it.

I set a good pace up the hill to the gap, and noted that I felt as fit as I had prior to my 3000s attempt in the summer for the first time since. We cleared the gap whilst it was still in good light, and indeed did not require the head torch to reach the car.

On the Thursday I felt that my right knee was very sore and immediately abandoned my plans to walk every day. I went to Aviemore and then Inverness with Andy Brown, procuring Butterfield's 'High Mountains' a book called 'The Black Cloud' which details Scottish mountain accidents and is absolutely fantastic, in addition to a new pair of Marmot 'Borealis' gloves. I was delighted to discover that as I have tiny hands I required child size gloves at half the price of the adult's!!!!

On the friday I also did not walk, and it turned out to be a fabulous day. I regretted this decision, as my knee felt ok after a brisk stroll up the road, but with retrospect it was the right decision. I'm hoping that a couple of weeks rest will allow it to heal sufficiently.

items.title: Ascent of Meall Chuaich and Creag Ruadh
items.content_html: With my team splitting up for the day today, I walked with Guy and Maggie, Rob, John and Claire.The reviews of Meall Chuaich possibly are not the best, but I thought that it was not too bad to be fair. The walk in from the A9 is horrendous with the viaduct ever present, but once this has been passed the remainder of the day is quite agreeable.The ridge onto Meall is fairly steep but broad, with a number of false summits, each of which disappoints. Eventually we did arrive on the top where we were greeted by a rather large cairn. Splitting on the summit, Guy Maggie and Claire returned by the route of ascent, whilst myself Rob and John headed towards Creag Ruadh.John led Rob and I down a slope which at the very best may be described as precipituous, and a number of falls in the heather did absolutely nothing to help my knee!After crossing the deer fence we paused for lunch before heading very steeply up the face of Creag Ruadh. About two thirds of the way up we hit a path which led up to the ridge rather more gradually, and a short stroll took us on to the summit, along with the usual debate about which rock was th highest. I found Creag Ruadh to be much more interesting than Meal Chuaich, enjoying a good view over Allt Cuaich, which interestingly does not have an h after the c!!!!(Or at least not in Butterfield).

items.title: Ascent of Lochangar from Spittal of Glenmuick
items.content_html: We knew that the weather would be atrocious today around the Cairngorms, but better in the East. When Tim and Ian suggested Lochnagar, I probably didn’t know that it was THAT far east!!!!Arriving at the Spittal of Glenmuick car park approximately 11:30 we knew when we started walking that we would be hard pushed to return by daylight. Tim didn’t last long due to a blister, and regrettably had to spend most of the afternoon in my car. Ian and I pushed up the landrover track besides Conachraig, and followed the subsequent track up to below Meikle Pap, which we did not ascend. Pausing briefly for a bite to eat, we had a view of the Great Cliffs as we topped the col, but then ascended immediately into the cloud on a steep boulder field leading up onto Lochnagar.When we hit this ridge, we knew that the climbing was pretty much done for the day, but finding the summit may be more problematic, as neither of us generally use a GPS for routefinding, and visibility was poor. As it turned out we needn’t have worried, following the cliffs from above, the top of Cac Carn More was easily visible, and a bearing took us without difficulty to the summit of Cac Carn Beag. We were disappointed not to obtain a good view, however we were grateful to be in a cloud that was essentially dry. Ian had his eye on a few of the gullies, but it was obvious that they were pretty bare on the tops on t’other side, and there were large unstable cornice' on our side.Rather than return the same way, we opted to descend via Glas Allt, and past a rather nice waterfall. Hitting the landrover track beside Loch Muick, we returned to the car just as the light was failing.

We knew that the weather would be atrocious today around the Cairngorms, but better in the East. When Tim and Ian suggested Lochnagar, I probably didn't know that it was THAT far east!!!!

Arriving at the Spittal of Glenmuick car park approximately 11:30 we knew when we started walking that we would be hard pushed to return by daylight. Tim didn't last long due to a blister, and regrettably had to spend most of the afternoon in my car. Ian and I pushed up the landrover track besides Conachraig, and followed the subsequent track up to below Meikle Pap, which we did not ascend. Pausing briefly for a bite to eat, we had a view of the Great Cliffs as we topped the col, but then ascended immediately into the cloud on a steep boulder field leading up onto Lochnagar.

When we hit this ridge, we knew that the climbing was pretty much done for the day, but finding the summit may be more problematic, as neither of us generally use a GPS for routefinding, and visibility was poor. As it turned out we needn't have worried, following the cliffs from above, the top of Cac Carn More was easily visible, and a bearing took us without difficulty to the summit of Cac Carn Beag. We were disappointed not to obtain a good view, however we were grateful to be in a cloud that was essentially dry. Ian had his eye on a few of the gullies, but it was obvious that they were pretty bare on the tops on t'other side, and there were large unstable cornice' on our side.

Rather than return the same way, we opted to descend via Glas Allt, and past a rather nice waterfall. Hitting the landrover track beside Loch Muick, we returned to the car just as the light was failing.

items.title: A traverse of Bynack More and Bynack Beg from Glenmore Lodge
items.content_html: Whilst for most people the Sunday was a bit of a warm-up, I was feeling pretty crap after getting battered by the weather the day prior. Ian and Tim had opted to go up Bynack More from Glenmore Lodge, and I thought that I might tag along.As everybody else spent the day on various sections of the plateau in the cloud, we enjoyed a rather pleasant stroll from Glenmore Lodge, past Ryvoan Bothy, and up a very gradual slope up to Bynack More.As you ascend said slope, it always appears that their will be a considerable drop prior to Bynack More, however this is a misconception. The ridge first levels out, and then drops maybe 10m, before climbing very steeply to the summit ridge.We paused at this col for a bite to eat, before pressing on with our relentless ascent, always conscious that the guidebook times would bring us down in the dark, and that the weather was closing in. We hit the summit about an hour before the clouds did in the end.The summit of Bynack More is covered in large boulders that were covered in snow and ice today. Pausing for maybe a quarter of an hour to take in the panorama, we began to descend with the clouds ominously close. Visiting the top of Bynack Beg, we descended directly down its nose into Strath Nethy.The path through Strath Nethy isn’t the best, and it is rather easy to both lose and gain, but we were soon on the landrover track heading back to Glenmore Lodge and the car.
items.content_text:
Whilst for most people the Sunday was a bit of a warm-up, I was feeling pretty crap after getting battered by the weather the day prior. Ian and Tim had opted to go up Bynack More from Glenmore Lodge, and I thought that I might tag along.

As everybody else spent the day on various sections of the plateau in the cloud, we enjoyed a rather pleasant stroll from Glenmore Lodge, past Ryvoan Bothy, and up a very gradual slope up to Bynack More.

As you ascend said slope, it always appears that their will be a considerable drop prior to Bynack More, however this is a misconception. The ridge first levels out, and then drops maybe 10m, before climbing very steeply to the summit ridge.

We paused at this col for a bite to eat, before pressing on with our relentless ascent, always conscious that the guidebook times would bring us down in the dark, and that the weather was closing in. We hit the summit about an hour before the clouds did in the end.

The summit of Bynack More is covered in large boulders that were covered in snow and ice today. Pausing for maybe a quarter of an hour to take in the panorama, we began to descend with the clouds ominously close. Visiting the top of Bynack Beg, we descended directly down its nose into Strath Nethy.

The path through Strath Nethy isn't the best, and it is rather easy to both lose and gain, but we were soon on the landrover track heading back to Glenmore Lodge and the car.

items.title: Traverse of Chno Dearg and Stob Coire Sgriodain from Fersit
items.content_html: Having opted to drive upto Newtonmore on the Friday this year, and to spend the extra night in the hotel, I was able to get an extra outing in. Feeling fairly tired from the exertions of the previous day, not to forget 3 hours stuck in traffic at Stoke, I didn’t feel great setting out.I walked on the Saturday with Andy Brown, Peter, John Eadon, and Fred. The weather was a little short of abysmal, I don’t think that any of us particularly enjoyed the walk. Andy drove to Fersit, which sits just south of Tulloch Station on the flanks of Loch Treig. We spent the majority of the walk in the cloud, and the weather was far too warm to permit the snow underfoot to be anything other than slushy. I was much happier underfoot though than I was on Beinn a Bheithir at New Year.Leaving the car park at Fersit we made our way through some farm buildings, and after being castigated by the farmer for trying to use the wrong gate, we finally gained the hillside. We followed the stream up towards Lochan Coire an Lochain before heading up through a wide gully onto Sron na Garbh - bheinne. Battling away on the ridge in poor visibility we finally found the summit of Stob Coire Sgriodain with a little assistance from Andy’s GPS. We then followed the ridge over the South Top, and down to the coll that sits between Stob Coire Sgriodain and Chno Dearg.At this point I believe that we tried to ascend from too low a point, and consequently spent a great deal of time pratting about with the GPS trying to find the summit, which we eventually did.The descent from Chno Dearg is a rather nice gradual slope, and we soon found ourselves out of the cloud and below the snow line, and racing back to watch the rugby.

At this point I believe that we tried to ascend from too low a point, and consequently spent a great deal of time pratting about with the GPS trying to find the summit, which we eventually did.

The descent from Chno Dearg is a rather nice gradual slope, and we soon found ourselves out of the cloud and below the snow line, and racing back to watch the rugby.

items.title: Ascents of Place Fell and Hallin Fell
items.content_html: Today was very much the lull that precedes the week at Newtonmore that is coming up in a weeks time. With the weather looking pretty miserable, and my wishing to force the Marilyn counter along a tad I opted for Place Fell and Hallin Fell along with Darren, Sarah and Rob, who I’d not met before.The pull up to Boredale Hause felt steeper than it looked on the map, but I think that in part that was due to the crampons and axes in my sac. Starting at about 11:00, we had summited Place Fell by 12:30, and paused momentarily to eat.Descending from Place Fell, Sarah and Rob opted for the coastal walk back to the coach at Glenriddings, Darren and myself opted for Hallin Fell and the stemer back.I had miscalculated the amount of ascent on to Hallin Fell, and we raced up it to allow us to make the 15:10 steamer. No sooner had it dawned on me that there was 100m less ascent than I had calculated, we were confronted bt the summit obelisk. The views from this fell were pretty good on a dull and dreary day, so I would imagine that they would be awesome on a better one.Arriving first back at the coach to get changed, it wasn’t log before we were propping up the bar in the Traveller’s Rest.
items.content_text:
Today was very much the lull that precedes the week at Newtonmore that is coming up in a weeks time. With the weather looking pretty miserable, and my wishing to force the Marilyn counter along a tad I opted for Place Fell and Hallin Fell along with Darren, Sarah and Rob, who I'd not met before.

The pull up to Boredale Hause felt steeper than it looked on the map, but I think that in part that was due to the crampons and axes in my sac. Starting at about 11:00, we had summited Place Fell by 12:30, and paused momentarily to eat.

Descending from Place Fell, Sarah and Rob opted for the coastal walk back to the coach at Glenriddings, Darren and myself opted for Hallin Fell and the stemer back.

I had miscalculated the amount of ascent on to Hallin Fell, and we raced up it to allow us to make the 15:10 steamer. No sooner had it dawned on me that there was 100m less ascent than I had calculated, we were confronted bt the summit obelisk. The views from this fell were pretty good on a dull and dreary day, so I would imagine that they would be awesome on a better one.

Arriving first back at the coach to get changed, it wasn't log before we were propping up the bar in the Traveller's Rest.

items.title: Hergest Ridge and Bradnor Hill
items.content_html: I dont think I need to say too much about this weekend (see also28th January 2006). As the pictures pretty much tell the story.On the Sunday we walked from Kington up over Hergest Ridge. The route is nice and gentle, so much so that Fred pushed young Katie up in her pushcair to the very summit. The group split here, with most of the party returning back along the ridge into Kington. Myself, Andy Brown, Mike, Guy, Sarah, Richard, and Lord John of Leintwardine proceeded in the general direction of Bradnor Hill.Whilst the ascent up Bradnor Hill is forestry track for approximately 3/4 of the way, we came to a strecth of felled forest which we made our way through in some discomfort. This being with the exception of the rather weedy characters who skirted around the long way - and no the pink shirt wearing J20 drinker was not one of them!!!!!!The top of Bradnor Hill is a rather bizarre place, where one treks through a number of holes on the golf course to attain the highest point. The buggy tack affords a quick descent back into Kington.

items.title: A Great Rhos circuit
items.content_html: I dont think I need to say too much about this weekend (see also29th January 2006). As the pictures pretty much tell the story.On the Saturday, after recovering oneself from bed, I promptly drove up with Mike and Sarah from Kington YHA and met up with the remainder of our group at New Radnor.Taking to the hillside we rose gently alongside Harley Dingle to reach the plateau like top of Great Rhos. A trek through the heather soon revealed the location of the trigonometry point. We then proceeded into the forest for lunch, before following the ridge along to the mast on Black Mixen, and to Bache Hill, taking in Little Creigiau on the way. Apparently this is a top on one of John Hipwood’s lists, although I am not familiar with it. We then procceded over Whimble, and descended along Harley Dingle into New Radnor. Here the non-drinking members of the party enjoyed a few pints in a rather nice pub entitled the Eagle.

items.title: Traverse of Moel Eilio
items.content_html: A pleasant stroll with Andy, Jan and Sarah. Walking from Llanberis, we headed up Maesgwm to the Bwlch between Moel Cynghorion and Foel Goch. We headed up over Foel Goch, Foel Gron, and Moel Eilio, before heading down the directmost of the two ridges leading down into Llanberis.I chose this route as I had been intending for some time to ‘do’ Eilio, and with the forecast abysmal, it seemed a good option. The weather was never really as bad as the forecasts suggested, though I’d imagine it was pretty arctic on top of Snowdon. The rain became heavier during the afternoon, and we were to get wet returning from Pete’s Eats to the coach!And as I am not bagging I did not know that this was Marilyn number 64!!!!!!!!
items.content_text:
A pleasant stroll with Andy, Jan and Sarah. Walking from Llanberis, we headed up Maesgwm to the Bwlch between Moel Cynghorion and Foel Goch. We headed up over Foel Goch, Foel Gron, and Moel Eilio, before heading down the directmost of the two ridges leading down into Llanberis.

I chose this route as I had been intending for some time to 'do' Eilio, and with the forecast abysmal, it seemed a good option. The weather was never really as bad as the forecasts suggested, though I'd imagine it was pretty arctic on top of Snowdon. The rain became heavier during the afternoon, and we were to get wet returning from Pete's Eats to the coach!

And as I am not bagging I did not know that this was Marilyn number 64!!!!!!!!

items.title: Ascent of Ysgyryd Fawr
items.content_html: This meet was the clubs new year trip, which is essentially a very social meet. A large led walk of about 40 people were led by John Eadon and myself from Llanvihangel-Crucorney across the fields to join the Beacons Wat. Skirting around the West flank of the hill we rejoined the Beacons Way South of Ysgyryd Fawr, and ascended the hill from the South. We enjoyed a rather nice stroll along the ridge which had received a peppering of snow. Summiting the hill we turned back south for about 200m to join the track heading East off the hill, and returned to the Skirrid Inn by the rout we had come in upon, with one notable short cut.Won’t say too much about certain mutineering led walkers except the following. If you play the game as well as you talk it why are you on a led walk? Furthermore, why don’t you lead one? I think that states my position in no uncertain terms.
items.content_text:
